acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: These records were transferred from the Clerk's office to the State Law Library in 2006.

bioghist.head: Historical Information
bioghist.p: The Clerk of the Supreme Court of Virginia is the officer of the court responsible for overseeing filings with the Court and maintaining its records. Maury B. Watts was appointed Clerk in 1933 and served until his death in 1952; Howard G. Turner served from 1952 to 1977, and David Beach served from 1977 to 2003.

The Special Court of Appeals was established by the General Assembly to relieve congestion of the high court docket by abjudicating cases assigned to it by the state Supreme Court. It met from 1924 to 1928.
The Judicial Council was established by the General Assembly in 1928. It was relatively inactive between 1936 and 1847, when Chief Justice Hudgins revitalized it.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection contains correspondence files of the Office of the Clerk, Supreme Court of Virginia, documenting the Clerk's role in managing the records of the Court, maintaining communication with justices in their offices across the state, and managing administrative issues, especially during the period 1933 to 1952. The collection also contains records documenting the ceremonial history of the court. The collection is organized into the following series: Special Court of Appeals correspondence, 1924-1928; correspondence of the Judicial Council of Virginia, 1930-1935; Clerk's correspondence with individual justices, 1918-2005 (bulk 1928-1977), Clerk's general correspondence, 1929-1981; subject files documenting swearing-in ceremonies and investitures, 1965-2005; subject files documenting portrait presentations, resolutions of appreciation, and memorials, 1945-2004; subject files documenting court anniversaries, 1979-2004; justices' speeches, 1954-1975; and miscellaneous records, 1909-2001.

scopecontent.p: Correspondence regarding the organization of a Special Court of Appeals, 1924-1928, is comprised of letters from Justice Frederick Walker Sims, Court President, 1925-1925, and Justice Robert Prentis, Chief Justice, 1925-1931, with other justices, judges, and legislators, documenting efforts to establish a special Court of Appeals in Virginia and recommendations for members of the court. Correspondents include state Senators Robert J. Noel, Alfred C. Smith, and W. Worth Smith, Jr., Delegates George A. Bowles, Charles Henry Smith, and Thomas W. Ozlin, Speaker; Louis S. Epes, State Corporation Commission, attorney Eppa Hunton, Jr., and Richmond Judge Beverley T. Crump.

Judicial Council correspondence contains correspondence of Chief Justice Prentis, President of the Judicial Council; and M.B. Watts, Clerk of the Supreme Court and Secretary of the Judicial Council, 1930-1935. Correspondence documents organization and administration of the Judicial Council and the Council's work in seeking recommendations from lawyers and judges for changes to statues regulating the practice of law in Virginia. Correspondents include individuals invited to join the Council, representatives of Judicial Councils from other states, and Virginia attorneys and judges proposing changes in laws. The correspondence includes an exchange between Herbert G. Cochran, Norfolk Juvenile and Domestic Relations Court Judge, to Norfolk, and Chief Justice Prentis, 1931, regarding a request for the Council's help with the Virginia State Bar Association's Committee on Organization of the Bar; and a letter from Chief Justice Campbell to Governor Peery, 1935, requesting re-appropriation for the Council in the Governor's budget for 1936.

Clerk's correspondence with justices is comprised mostly of internal correspondence between the Clerk of the Supreme Court and the justices, but also includes some copies justices' correspondence with other people. There are several files of correspondence with Chief Justice Holt, 1928-1947; Chief Justice Hudgins, 1930-1958; Justice Gregory, 1933-1951, and Justice Spratley, 1936-1977. Correspondence pertains mostly to day-to-day administrative issues, editing and copy-editing of opinions, and management of court documents. Some letters from justices to the Clerk include rationales for decisions or opinions, references to court policies, concerns about declining health of other justices, and personal matters.

The series includes one file of correspondence of Justice Holt, 1937-1938, pertaining to portraits of St. George Tucker and Justice Chinn, a memorial plaque for Judge Carrington, and a portrait of St. George Tucker. Also included is a folder containing personal correspondence of Chief Justice Holt, 1944-1947, which is comprised mostly of short letters to his three two daughters, and personal friends.

Correspondence between Clerk Maury B. Watts and Chief Justice Hudgins includes correspondence regarding the Judicial Council of Virginia, 1947-1958. Of particular interest are letters from Chief Justice Hudgins protesting a bill pending in the House of Delegates in 1954 that would have required approval of the General Assembly of rules adopted by the Supreme Court, through the Judicial Council, affecting the practice of law in Virginia. A file of personal correspondence of Chief Justice Hudgins, 1941-1950, includes a letter from Senator A. Willis Robertson, 1947, responding to Hudgins' inquiry about legislation to help tobacco farmers and protect archaeological findings in the section of the Roanoke River Basin to be flooded by construction of the Buggs Island Dam.

Correspondence between M.B. Watts, Clerk, and Justice Spratley, 1936-1952, pertains mostly to Watts' editorial suggestions, research questions, and research advice, and some correspondence about Justice Spratley's law clerks in the early 1940s. Correspondence between Howard G. Turner, Clerk, and Justice Spratley, 1953-1977, pertains mostly to management of court documents, hiring of law clerks, and court ceremonies.

Much of the Clerk's correspondence, especially after M.B. Watt's death in 1952, is more limited and pertains pertains mostly to portrait presentations, retirements, and memorials. The collection contains smaller correspondence files with and/or about the following justices: Justice George Browning, 1938; Justice Archibald Buchanan, 1957; 1967-1991 (includes an article about Justice Buchanan and Chief Justice Eggleston in summer 1969 issue of The Record, the magazine of the Hampden-Sydney Alumni Association); Chief Justice Campbell, 1933-1947; Chief Justice Harry Carrico, 1969-1974 and 1996; Justice George Cochran, 1969-1999; Justice Asbury C. Compton, 1974-1999; Chief Justice John Eggleston, 1935; 1969-1977; Justice Thomas Gordon, 1978; Justice Alexander Harman, 1969-1988; Justice Albertis Harrison, 1954-1985; 1987; Chief Justice Lawrence I'Anson, 1965-1993; Justice Willis Miller, 1946-1949, Justice Richard Poff, 1972-1973; Justice Charles Russell, 1982; 1993; Justice Lemuel Smith, 1946; 1951-1956; Chief Justice Harold Snead, 1956; 1964-1982; Justice Abram Staples, 1951; Justice William Thompson, 1983; Justice Henry Whiting, 1997; 2005; and Justice Kennon Whittle, 1953-1965.

Clerk's general correspondence, 1929-1969, contains correspondence with other court clerks from around the state, including W.W. Smales, Deputy Clerk, Supreme Court of Appeals, Staunton; regarding planning of presentations of portraits and memorials to justices, 1929-1955 (Justice West, 1929; Chief Justice Prentis, 1931-1932; Circuit Court Judge Robert Richardson, 1939-1945; and Justice Hinton, who served in the nineteenth century, 1955; copies by the artist Nurnberger, 1963, and the loan of a potrait of St. George Tucker, 1963); admission of foreign attorneys, 1933-1942; cessation of court sessions in Staunton and Wytheville, 1938; regarding management of portraits, 1941-1968; requests for biographical information on former clerks George Taylor and John Brown, 1941 and 1959; the retirement of Justice Abram Staples, 1951; modifications to court rules, 1960 and 1981; alterations to the state library and supreme court building,1967; and a solicitation for business from Leo Fox, who approached clients using the pseudonym Charles J. Fox, 1969.

Speeches, 1954-1975, consist of an addresses by Justices Carrico, Eggleston, and I'anson dediciating portraits or memorials or about the functions of the court. Included is an address, 1975, by Justice Carrico to the Richmond Association of Attorneys' wives, 1975.

did.unittitle: Subject files: swearing in ceremonies and investitutures 1965-2005

scopecontent.p: Subject files on swearing-in ceremonies and investitures include invitations, programs, oaths of office, transcripts of ceremonies, speeches and remarks, and sometimes seating charts and ceremony planning notes. The collection contains materials documenting the swearing-in ceremonies or investitures of the following justices and other officers of the court: Justice Agee, 2003 Mar. 1 and 5; Justice George Cochran, 1969 Oct. 1; Justice Asbury C. Compton, 1974 Oct. 1; Justice Thomas Gordon, 1965 Feb. 17; Justice Alexander Harman, 1969 Oct. 1; Justice Leroy Hassell, 1989 Dec. 28; Chief Justice Hassell, 2003 Feb. 11; Chief Justice Warren I'Anson, 1974 Oct. 1; Justice Barbara Milano Keenan, 1991 Jul. 2; Justice Cynthia Kinser, 1997 Jun. 27; Justice Lawrence Koontz, 1995 Aug. 16; Justice Elizabeth Bermingham Lacey, 1989 Jan. 4; Justice Donald Lemons, 2000 Apr. 4; Justice Charles Russell, 1982 Mar. 5; Justice John Thomas, 1983 Apr. 25; Justice William Thompson, 1980 Feb. 1; and David Beach, Clerk, 1984 Oct. 31; Patricia Harrington, Clerk, 2003 Aug. 27; and Karl Hade, Executive Secretary, 2005 Sep. 12.

did.unittitle: Subject files: portrait presentations, resolutions of appreciation, and memorials 1945-2004

scopecontent.p: Subject files on portrait presentations, memorials, and resolutions of appreciations contain invitations, programs, transcripts of ceremonies, including remarks; printed memorials, resolutions of appreciation (legislative and judicial), planning notes, some seating charts, and newspaper clippings. The collection documents ceremonies honoring the following justices: Justice George Browning, 1948 Jan. 9; Justice Archibald Buchanan, 1954, 1969, and 1980; Chief Justice Preston Campbell, 1959; Chief Justice Harry Carrico, 1990, 2001; Justice Joseph Chinn, 1941; Justice George Cochran, 1989 Apr. 20; Justice Asbury C. Compton, 2000, circa; Chief Justice John Eggleston, 1976 Oct. 7; Justice Gordon, 2003-2004; Justice Herbert Gregory, 1952 Apr. 21; Justice Alexander Harman, 1989 Oct. 5; Justice Albertis Harrison, 1984 Oct. 12; Chief Justice Henry Holt, 1948; Chief Justice Edward Hudgins, 1958-1959; Chief Justice Lawrence I'Anson, 1983 Jun. 15; Justice James Keith (Court President), 1925 Oct. 30; Justice Willis Miller, 1961 Apr. 17; Chief Justice Harold Snead, 1982 Jun. 16; Justice Claude Spratley, 1977 Jun. 9; Justice Abram Staples, 1952 Apr. 21; David Beach, Clerk, 2003 Jun. 6; and Howard G. Turner, Clerk, 1952, 1977, and 1992.

Subject files on court anniversaries contain programs, speeches, transcripts, and correspondence documenting the 200th anniversary of the establishment of the Supreme Court of Virginia, 1979 Aug. 30 (program, speeches); the 200th anniversary of the first session of the Court, 1980 (correspondence); the 200th anniversary of the establishment of the federal judiciary, 1990 (transcript, correspondence); and the 225th anniversary of the establishment of the Virginia Supreme Court, 2004 (programs, transcript, invitation, certificate of recognition).

Miscellaneous records, 1909-2001, contain the application of Stanley Burt to Judge Jesse West, Surry County Circuit Court Judge, for a license to practice law, 1909; an employment questionnaire, M.B. Watts, Clerk of court, 1936; an order designating Justice Staples Chief Justice in Staunton, 1947 Nov. 21; building plans for alterations to the air conditioning system, State Library and Supreme Court buildings, 1958; a press release, 1989 Nov. 1, announcing retired Justice Thomas' return to Hunton and Williams law firm; a program, inscribed by Justice Miller, from a memorial to Judge John Johnson Parker, Chief Judge, Fourth Circuit, U.S. Court of Appeals, 1958 Apr. 22; Justice Carrico's oath of office, 1991 Jan. 25; and a memo from Justice Lacey to the Chief Justices and Justices, pertaining to multi-jurisdictional practice initiatives, 2001 Feb. 26.
